scientific_summary: Surprise can be startling or delightful. Orienting responses and meaning-making help integrate unexpected events (Meyer et al., 1997).

immediate.title: Orient and label
instructions: Pause and take one slow breath in through the nose and out through the mouth.
Name three details about what just happened (who, what, where).
Label the surprise as 'pleasant', 'unpleasant', or 'neutral' to reduce ambiguity.

evidence.summary: Cognitive appraisal theory shows labeling unexpected stimuli reduces arousal and guides coping.

immediate.title: Startle release
instructions: If the surprise felt jarring, roll your shoulders back and shake arms gently for ten seconds.
Stretch your neck side-to-side while exhaling slowly.
End with one diaphragmatic breath to signal the body the startle has passed.

evidence.summary: Gentle muscular release reduces residual startle responses and restores baseline arousal.

immediate.title: Five-sense reset
instructions: List aloud five things you can see, four you can touch, three you can hear, two you can smell, one you can taste.
Keep breaths slow while moving through the senses.
Note how your heart rate shifts as your brain registers safety.

evidence.source: American Psychological Association, Grounding Techniques Review, 2020
evidence.summary: Grounding through sensory orientation reduces shock and aids cognitive integration.

short_term.title: Meaning map
instructions: Write down the unexpected event and your initial reaction.
List two possible positive implications and two challenges created by the surprise.
Note one action you can take today to respond constructively.

evidence.summary: Meaning-making after unexpected events improves psychological adjustment.

short_term.title: Share the story
instructions: Tell a trusted person about the surprise in three sentences.
Ask them for one perspective or encouragement.
Write down any new insight gained from the conversation.

evidence.summary: Expressing surprising events verbally aids emotional processing and integration.

short_term.title: Next-step triage
instructions: Draft three quick questions: What is stable? What needs action? Who can help?
Answer each in one sentence to separate urgency from noise.
Schedule or perform the smallest viable action within the next hour.

evidence.summary: Rapid meaning-and-action planning improves resilience to unexpected change.

long_term.title: Cognitive flexibility practice
instructions: Pick a routine task and do it in a new order or environment (e.g., different route, new recipe).
Journal how the change felt and what you learned about adapting.
Rate your comfort with novelty from 1â€“10 and note trends over time.

evidence.summary: Practicing cognitive flexibility enhances resilience to unexpected events.

long_term.title: Growth reflection journal
instructions: List three surprises from the past month.
Identify what each taught you or how it nudged growth.
Set one intention for welcoming future positive surprises.

evidence.summary: Reflecting on unexpected events fosters post-traumatic and post-event growth.

long_term.title: Innovation journal
instructions: Record surprising moments that led to positive innovations or changes.
Identify patterns in how you responded well.
Set an intention to replicate one adaptive response in the coming month.

evidence.summary: Tracking positive surprise responses enhances psychological flexibility and growth.

friend_support.title: Ground with them
instructions: Invite your friend to breathe with you and describe what happened factually.
Reflect back the key feeling words you hear (startled, delighted, confused).
Ask what support they need next and offer one concrete option (call, plan, quiet time).

evidence.summary: Co-regulation with a trusted person stabilizes autonomic responses after startling events.

friend_support.title: Help them shape the story
instructions: Ask your friend to walk through the surprise chronologically while you take notes.
Highlight strengths and resources they used to handle it.
Offer to draft a summary text/email with them if action is required.

evidence.summary: Collaborative narrative construction increases coherence and emotional relief.

self_repair.title: Repair if I startled them
instructions: Acknowledge the unintentional surprise and its impact ("I jumped out and scared you; I see it spiked your heart rate").
Offer a sincere apology and validate their reaction.
Ask what boundaries they'd prefer for future surprises.

evidence.source: Baumeister et al., Review of General Psychology, 1994
evidence.summary: Acknowledging emotional impact and adjusting behavior restores trust after unwanted surprises.

self_repair.title: Make up for missing their surprise
instructions: If you failed to respond to their exciting surprise, plan a belated celebration (call, gift, shared activity).
Express genuine enthusiasm and reference the details you missed.
Set a reminder to acknowledge future surprises promptly.

evidence.summary: Responsive engagement with partners' positive events strengthens relational bonds after misses.
